data.text: Compact Bike Bag for Bicycle Touring

What's a good bike bag for the train that can easily be carried on the bike while touring? I'm thinking of taking the train between routes, skipping over the boring sections when they're long. For example, train to France, do some local loops, then train to Spain s and Portugal.

This is from New Zealand and works great and folds I to a really small size. We've used them for air travel. Not sure what you can get in Europe. https://www.groundeffect.co.nz/products/dogsbody-compact-bike-bag
Dogsbody
groundeffect.co.nz
data.author: Jenny Currie

data.text: yes, an excellent bag for a touring bike. I have used mine on several international flights. No problems with any damage; easy to pack away in a pannier. Only available on-line direct from Ground Effectâ€™s website.
data.author: Il Padrone

data.text: I really like Hilary's idea of shipping it to the final destination. How do you pack your other gear? Doesn't look like it would fit in this bag like it would a box? I do like the idea of this though, especially hearing you all say you've had no damage.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: We pack everything else into their panniers and use cheap duffel bags (or something similar that can be given away on arrival or folded up to carry) to hold all the panniers together for the flight.
data.author: Jenny Currie

data.text: same here, I just use those cheap red, white, blue bags and put the panniers in those. I then give the big bag to someone homeless etc and buy a new one on my return. Maybe not the most sustainable but it works.
data.author: Hilary King

data.text: What about if you're taking a flight/train to A, riding from there to B, and then taking another flight/train from B back home? Can you easily ship those bags along with the bike bag to B? I'm really liking this idea.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: that's why I Poste restante the bag to the final destination. Please note I do use additional padding in the bag for shipping on planes. Coming from Australia, my bike is used to flying. I just throw most of the padding away and pick up new stuff at my destination. I also use some of my luggage as packing as long as the total bag weighs under 23kg when packed.
data.author: Hilary King

data.text: when I travel all my other gear in panniers goes in a separate bag. Dumping it into a box would definitely blow the box beyond the 32kg max for oversized luggage. The box would probably bust open as well.
data.author: Il Padrone

data.text: and the Ground Effect bag is easy to carry with you on your bike (rear rack or inside a front pannier) on the tour.
data.author: Il Padrone

data.text: I thought my husband and I were the only ones that did this lol! We grab them at garage sales !
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: NO criticism of Ground Effect - they make high quality gear - but similar bags can be bought in Europe at a far cheaper price. I paid 12 euro for one that I bought in Spain at a bus station and carried it on my back rack whilst I rode the Camino. It had enough space that later I was able to semi dismantle two bikes to fit in and transport them back to New Zealand.
data.author: Biff Frederikson

data.text: wow, are those available at most bus stations in Spain? I'll be there in the next month.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text:
Not sure about Spain but the regional trains in France take bikes free of charge if there's room. Great info here. https://www.freewheelingfrance.com/planning-a-trip/bikes-and-french-trains.html
Taking bikes on French Trains - A Guide for Cyclists - Freewheeling France
freewheelingfrance.com
data.author: Michael Bond

data.text: It varies a lot between countries, and even within France the faster TGV does on some lines but not on others. I was just in south africa, and buses wouldn't take unboxed bikes.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: Ground effect tardis bag. Folds up to the size of team of A4. I just poste restante it to my final destination so I don't have to carry it. I have travelled all over the world with this bag successfully. Also useful that when loaded, it comfortably fits in the back of my corolla with the seat down. Much smaller and easier to manage than a bike box.
data.author: Hilary King

data.text: and you carry this bag with you for the entire trip?
data.author: Cynthia Nielson

data.text: as mentioned above I posted restante it to my final destination. No need or desire to travel with it.
data.author: Hilary King

data.text: Just curious why you want a bag to take a bike on the train? I've taken bikes on trains in several countries and never needed a bag. Not sure which ones do? If I felt I needed a bag, I'd probably just use the CTC plastic one.. was the cheapest and lightest one I could find for carrying & flying back at the end.
data.author: Richard Goodman

data.text: depends on the train. Eurostar and some tgv lines in France require it for example. Most coach style busses do too.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta
